fields.headline: Portico Quartet: Live/Remix – review
fields.bodyText: They used to be buskers, but this double-album (half drawn from last year's live shows; the other half remixes by producers including Will Ward, Scratcha DVA and Berlin club DJ Luca Lozano) catches the sweeping big-venue confidence and charisma of Portico Quartet's recent performances with a rare balance of studio-like clarity and audience presence. They play London's Koko with guests, including Swedish vocalist Cornelia, on 17 April; a gig likely to reveal just how far they've come in imparting deeper levels and richer nuances to a repertoire populated by disarmingly artless themes. Much of the music was on last year's studio album - including the loping Window Seat with its swooping string sounds, the violin-like sax melody of Ruins, and the initially dreamy and then hauntingly intense Rubidium. Sleepless, delivered by Cornelia here with a fragility (clustered around by her own church-like echo) that swells to soulful cries, represents some of the most memorable moments of a memorable set. Portico were prone to noodliness in their early days, as if they were waiting for the instrumental skills that could elaborate on their catchy compositions. Now they've developed a textural palette that's bypassed that problem, and in the process taken their emotional clout to another level.
